author: Bob Seidenberg
title: Evanston, Northwestern announce details of $1 million donation - Evanston Review
text:
Evanston Mayor Elizabeth Tisdahl and Northwestern University President Morton Schapiro have announced the allocation of the first $1 million from the university to go to city services and programs, ranging from a major Sheridan Road Improvement project, to assistance to paramedics and city outreach workers who work with at-risk youth.
The duo announced Friday the first of the $1 million donations from the university over a five-year period. The money will go to the city's Good Neighbor Fund.
"The Good Neighbor Fund's allocation for year one is being directed towards projects that will help Evanston reach its goal of becoming the most livable city," Tisdahl said in the announcement. "Northwestern is a great university, and its presence strengthens our community. I thank President Schapiro for the Good Neighbor policy and look forward to seeing positive outcomes from this generous donation."

(Blair Kamin) Tisdahl said in her State of the City address in last March the university had agreed to donate the $1 million annually to the city for a period of five years with proceeds to be spent on projects and services agreed to jointly by the mayor and Schapiro.
"One of Northwestern's greatest assets is its location in Evanston, and we are so pleased to offer our assistance as part of our contribution to Evanston's Good Neighbor Fund," Schapiro said. "We look forward to working together and providing additional support to the city on important Evanston projects and initiatives in the future."
The university, which is tax-exempt from paying property taxes under state charter, has donated sporadically to the city in the past, including funding the cost of a new fire truck in 2009.
However, the announcement in March was the first time the university had committed to donations over a specified period of time.
Tisdahl and Schapiro agreed to the following allocations following a meeting of the two top officials, the university said in its announcement on Friday.

(Bob Seidenberg) The allocations are:
•$500,000 — to go toward a Sheridan Road improvement project, still in its early stages. This project will continue into 2016 with its design phase and is to be fully completed in 2017.
•$200,000 — in support for Evanston Fire Department paramedics. The allocation represents the cost of one full-time ambulance company serving the community 24/7 for a period of one year, officials said. Evanston provides fire and ambulance services to the private university, which doesn't have its own fire department.
•$100,000 — in support for the city's Youth and Young Adult Division. This allocation will cover the salary of one of the four existing full-time outreach workers and allow the City to add an additional full-time outreach worker.
•$150,000 — in support for at-risk youth job training programs, with $50,000 going to support programs covered by existing funding and $100,000 devoted to new job training programs.
•$50,000 — to go toward support for the mayor's fund to assist families impacted by violent crime.
